s.text: "The correlation between animal protein [intake] and fracture rates in different societies is as strong as that between lung cancer and smoking," says T. Colin Campbell, professor of nutritional biochemistry at Cornell University.
But it's a difficult balance to strike when it's common for Americans to eat double the protein we need, with 70 percent of it coming from animal sources.

While they're fighting, they forgot to notice the audience is at American Pie . So it turns out that no matter who is right, the calcium doubters or the calcium advocates, that shattering sound you will hear as the 21 st century progresses will be America's bones.
The problem with this theory is that recent studies show that the Chinese diet is rapidly becoming more Westernized.
The problem with this theory is that recent studies show that the Chinese diet is rapidly becoming more Westernized.
Chinese women have only about two-thirds of the amount of circulating estrogen that American women do, which helps account for their far lower rate of breast cancer, says Campbell.
They also have about 40 percent the rate of hip fracture of the West.
Chinese women have only about two-thirds of the amount of circulating estrogen that American women do, which helps account for their far lower rate of breast cancer, says Campbell.
They also have about 40 percent the rate of hip fracture of the West.
But following menopause, the British women end up losing more bone than the Japanese.
Early in life, American girls consume lots of these, which leads to relatively dense bones, high levels of estrogen, and early sexual maturation.
Conversely, high calcium consumption causes the body to decrease the amount of the mineral that is absorbed, excreting the excess.

Robert Heaney, professor of medicine at the Creighton University School of Medicine and a proponent of high dairy consumption, found in a study he co-authored that the "single most important determinate of the rate of bone gain" in young women was not the amount of calcium consumed but the ratio of calcium to protein.
Eating animal protein, which is high in sulfur-containing amino acids, requires the body to buffer the effects of those amino acids.
That's why populations with low calcium consumption manage to form healthy skeletons, and high calcium consumers don't develop bones like mastodons.

While they're fighting, they forgot to notice the audience is at American Pie . So it turns out that no matter who is right, the calcium doubters or the calcium advocates, that shattering sound you will hear as the 21 st century progresses will be America's bones.

But most of all, they say, forget population statistics and instead look at the laboratory.
But it's a difficult balance to strike when it's common for Americans to eat double the protein we need, with 70 percent of it coming from animal sources.
The milk proponents offer a variety of responses as to why osteoporosis is far less common in the nonmilk-drinking world.

With an aging population, and in the absence of some plumbing apocalypse that will cause Americans to adopt a squatting posture to relieve themselves, the incidence and cost of osteoporosis can only rise.
